head.supplied: Melbourne bot Garden, ¶ 15/5/73 ¶ Sir ¶ ¶ In compliance with your request, conveyed in your communication of the 3 inst. ¶ I have the honor to submit herewith a return of all plants, seeds, cuttings...

div.p: K73/8977, unit 750, VPRS 44/P inward registered and unregistered correspondence, VA 538 Department of Crown Lands and Survey, Public Record Office, Victoria.

MS file annotations:
By J. J. Casey: 'Mr Wallis | Analyse this return for me. Seperate the foreign exportations from those sent to the interior of Victoria distinguish — seeds plants trees &c | Those sent to places in Victoria — separate into churches Pub builgs public men & private individuals | J.J.C. 21.5.73'.
By A. R. Wallis: 'Analysis herewith. In making the within analysis it has been found necessary to deviate slightly from the headings laid down. For example, to public buildings have been added public grounds, to public men public bodies, to private individuals several items that could not be placed under any of the previous headings. A. R. Wallis 26.5.73'.
In a different hand: 'Return to Sect for Agriculture'. Melbourne bot Garden,

In compliance with your request, conveyed in your communication of the 3 inst.
Letter not found. I have the honor to submit herewith a return of all plants, seeds, cuttings &c furnished from the botanic Garden during the year 1870. The only entries, which are not made, are those of fresh medicinal herbs, flowers or roots, supplied to patients on request of legitimate practioners,
practitioners? further fresh leaves of the White Mulberry trees for Silkworm-food, also flowers for objects of drawing or painting or modelling &c, which to enter it was deemed a mere waste of time. The plants, supplied to churches, schools, cemeteries and other public institutions were to a very great extent strong pot-grown plants. Should the return be required to be still more explicative, then it can be enlarged.

div.p: I have the honor to be,

div.p: The distributions of 1870 stand in a fair average proportion to those of the other 16 years of my Directorship.
The honorable the Minister of Lands.

Distributions from the Botanic Garden of Melbourne during 1870.
The list that follows is in Georg Luehmann's hand, with corrections and additions by M as noted. A slightly simplified version of the list is published in Maroske & May (1993). Not all persons in the list have been identified; those that have been are included in the Biographical Register.
Peter Lawson & Son, Seedsmen, Edinburgh, 30 species Austral seeds in small lots, in interchange
Conservator of Forests, Amritsar, India 13 sp. do do

The list is followed in the file by an analysis of the data along the lines called for by Minister Casey, headed 'General Summary of Distributions from Melbourne Botanic Gardens during the year 1870'. The analysis comprises a tabulated 'General Analysis of Distributions from Melbourne Botanic Garden for year 1870', followed by detailed tables in which the information provided by M is rearranged so as to correspond to the categories of distribution shown in the general analysis: 'Foreign Distributions from Melb. Bot. Gard Year 1870', 'Return of distributions from the Botanic Garden of Melbourne to Churches in Victoria during the year 1870', 'Distribution of Plants &c to Public Buildings and Grounds in Victoria from Melb. Bot. Gardens 1870', and 'Distribution of Plants &c from Melb. Botanic Garden to Private bodies and individuals during the year 1870'. There is a further, short list, 'Distribution of Plants &c to Public bodies and Individuals in Victoria (from the Melbourne Bot. Garden) during the year 1870', for which there is no corresponding line in the general analysis. For the purposes of the analysis, 'foreign' is defined to refer to all distributions 'to places beyond the Booundary of Victoria'.
